definition: (TCM) six bowels (hollow organs), namely: gall bladder 膽|胆[dan3], stomach 胃[wei4], large intestine 大腸|大肠[da4 chang2], small intestine 小腸|小肠[xiao3 chang2], triple heater 三焦[san1 jiao1], bladder 膀胱[pang2 guang1]

sentences.english: The derrnatopathy with room only for you alone.
sentences.chinese: 单独与房间只为你的五脏六腑。

sentences.english: Would like to know internal organs of the day to run law?
sentences.chinese: 想知道五脏六腑在一天中的运行规律吗？

sentences.english: My lower insides erupted into electrical voltage and flames.
sentences.chinese: 我的五脏六腑爆发为低电压和火焰。

sentences.english: Winston's entrails seemed to have turned into ice.
sentences.chinese: 温斯顿的五脏六腑似乎都变成了冰块。

sentences.english: We're going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads of our tanks.
sentences.chinese: 我们还要掏出他们的五脏六腑来润滑我们的坦克履带。

sentences.english: Therefore, the study interest rises sharply, the viscera is full of fresh air.
sentences.chinese: 于是，学习的兴趣大涨，五脏六腑都觉得清新。

definition: five viscera of TCM, namely: heart 心[xin1], liver 肝[gan1], spleen 脾[pi2], lungs 肺[fei4] and kidneys 腎|肾[shen4]
(TCM) the three truncal cavities (thoracic, abdominal and pelvic), known as the "triple heater" or "San Jiao"
qi and blood (two basic bodily fluids of Chinese medicine)
spleen and stomach (digestive organs in TCM)/preferences/one's taste (e.g. in literature)

acupuncture point (any point on any meridian)/category of 12 specific acupuncture points near the wrist or ankle, each lying on a different meridian (one of five categories collectively termed 五輸穴|五输穴)
bodily fluids (general term in Chinese medicine)
one of the channels of TCM
